summary:
I am Nova, a humanitarian architect, and development practitioner. Graduating with an MSc in Urban Management and Development(Dec 2020) from IHS( Institute for Housing and Urban Development Studies), Erasmus University, I specialized in strategic urban planning.

Before that, I completed a Bachelor of Architecture(2013) from BRAC(Bangladesh Rural Advancement Committee) University in Bangladesh. With over nine years(2012-) of professional experience, I worked on multifaceted projects contributing to the sustainable development of cities and communities.

My expertise asserts,
-Sustainable Architecture
-Housing Upgradation; Low-Cost Housing for marginalized communities
-Climate-adaptive Infrastructure and Testing of Prototypes
-Urban Wash Service
-Participatory Community Development
-M&E( Monitoring and Evaluation)
-Sustainable Development Goals (SDG5, SDG6, SDG7, SDG11, and SDG13)

awards.title: Honorable Mention in  Urban Innovation Challenge
awards.description:
'Urban Innovation Challenge,' a competition arranged by BRAC Ngo in 2018, awards 
innovative and inclusive business models to promote socially sustainable 
entrepreneurship. Hence, the winning teams receive seed funding money to prototype 
their proposed business models. I led a multidisciplinary team and received the honorable 
mention in this competition under SDG 6: The Clean Water and Sanitation-category. Our 
business model proposed to scale up Urban Rainwater Harvesting in the big cities and 
coastal belt (salinity affected areas) of Bangladesh. Therefore, following that, we got to 
scale up our business model, including constructing a prototype, in the next eight months.

awards.title: Winner in 'Confronting Informality' by TU Delft
awards.description:
I won in the Ideas Competition, 'Confronting Informality in June 2018. This competition was part of a symposium, arranged by the Department of Urbanism of the TU Delft, to discuss informal urbanization in the Global South. I led the multidisciplinary team comprising three architects, a public health expert, and a community immobilizer. 

“Confronting Informality: Preserving communities and creating public goods in informal settlements”, Delft University of Technology, 2018

profile_positions.description:
Shakhipur Co-compost plant is a waste recycling project located in Tangail, Bangladesh. WaterAid Bangladesh was the technical design consultant of this project, whereas Shakhipur Municipality implemented it. The technology of this plant is to collect fecal sludge and solid waste and recycle it afterward. Eventually, it converts them into soil conditioners to improve the land quality. To date, Shakhipur Municipality is managing this co-compost plant. Being an environment-friendly project, it gained many awards. Moreover, it was chosen to exhibit in the 6th South Asian Conference on Sanitation (SACOSAN VI).
My duties included:
As a 3d Modeler, I was recruited by WaterAid Bangladesh to prepare two sectional models, drawings on how to set it up, and 3D animations for SACOSAN VI. I also collaborated with Mirpur Agricultural Workshop and Training School (MAWTS), a technical institute to make the models. It helped me make miniatures of the machinery used in the co-compost plan. Models, Drawing, and 3D animation were used as educational materials at the SACOSAN VI conference.

volunteer_experiences.description: I was part of the Public Life and Public Space (PSPL) surveys supervised by the Gehl Architects. The World Bank supported this quantitative survey in Gulshan and Banani, two prime locations of Dhaka Metropolitan. It measured the existing pedestrian flows and the traffic volumes of Dhaka North's central nodes and streets.

I was a surveyor of the Public Life and Public Space (PSPL) surveys supervised by the Gehl Architects. The World Bank supported this quantitative survey in the old Dhaka area, the southern part of the Metropolitan. It measured the existing pedestrian flows and traffic volumes in Dhaka South's central nodes and nearby areas. It also mapped pedestrian activities in public spaces.
I was awarded a fellowship for 4 days of long-professional training on Urban Rainwater Harvesting, arranged by WaterAid Bangladesh and CSE(Centre for Science and Environment).
